# Pandas

## Introduction

`pandas` is the Python Data Analysis package. It allows for data ingestion, transformation and cleaning, and creates objects that can then be passed on to analytic packages like `statsmodels` and `scikit-learn` for modeling and packages like `matplotlib`, `seaborn`, and `plotly` for visualization. 

`pandas` is built on top of numpy, so many numpy functions are commonly used in manipulating `pandas` objects. 

> `pandas` is a pretty extensive package, and we'll only be able to cover some of its features. For more details, there is free online documentation at [pandas.pydata.org](https://pandas.pydata.org). You can also look at the book ["Python for Data Analysis (2nd edition)"](https://www.amazon.com/Python-Data-Analysis-Wrangling-IPython-dp-1491957662/dp/1491957662/) by Wes McKinney, the original developer of the pandas package, for more details.

## Starting pandas

As with any Python module, you have to "activate" `pandas` by using `import`. The "standard" alias for `pandas` is `pd`. We will also import `numpy`, since `pandas` uses some `numpy` functions in the workflows. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-2, executionInfo={'elapsed': 384, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189378172, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="n7x8jkM07iuN"}
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
```
<!-- #region id="MD6c1ATU7iuN" -->
## Data import and export

Most data sets you will work with are set up in tables, so are rectangular in shape. Think Excel spreadsheets. In `pandas` the structure that will hold this kind of data is a `DataFrame`.  We can read external data into a `DataFrame` using one of many `read_*` functions. We can also write from a `DataFrame` to a variety of formats using `to_*` functions. The most common of these are listed below:

| Format type | Description | reader       | writer     |
| ----------- | ----------- | ------------ | ---------- |
| text        | CSV         | read_csv     | to_csv     |
|             | Excel       | read_excel   | to_excel   |
| text        | JSON        | read_json    | to_json    |
| binary      | Feather     | read_feather | to_feather |
| binary      | SAS         | read_sas     |            |
| SQL         | SQL         | read_sql     | to_sql     |

We'll start by reading in the `mtcars` dataset stored as a CSV file

## Data structures and types

pandas has two main data types: `Series` and `DataFrame`. These are analogous to vectors and matrices, in that a `Series` is 1-dimensional while a `DataFrame` is 2-dimensional. 

### pandas.Series

The `Series` object holds data from a single input variable, and is required, much like numpy arrays, to be homogeneous in type. You can create `Series` objects from lists or numpy arrays quite easily
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-11, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 405, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189526796, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="uDQmAdUB7iuN", outputId="fb27f769-e4b3-4d7b-9756-7a69ecb078c3"}
s = pd.Series([1,3,5,np.nan, 9, 13])
s
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-12, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 237, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189526964, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="8OcKC1Jp7iuN", outputId="ddd2bf46-bc33-4449-9f33-e22592be1fcf"}
s2 = pd.Series(np.arange(1,20))
s2
```
<!-- #region id="qOei4Fpm7iuN" -->
You can access elements of a `Series` much like a `dict`
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-13, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 298, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189527580, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="HtnjTRhy7iuN", outputId="f051e6e7-3563-4c35-d5ab-b7adfcc488ec"}

```{python 02-python-pandas-14, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 311, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189528089, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="eUNh4pze7iuO", outputId="7dd01693-7bfe-4a7a-80a8-126b2deb4e04"}

### pandas.DataFrame

The `DataFrame` object holds a rectangular data set. Each column of a `DataFrame` is a `Series` object. This means that each column of a `DataFrame` must be comprised of data of the same type, but different columns can hold data of different types. This structure is extremely useful in practical data science. The invention of this structure was, in my opinion, transformative in making Python an effective data science tool.
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="U_KhDQmf7iuO" -->
#### Creating a DataFrame

The `DataFrame` can be created by importing data, as we saw in the previous section. It can also be created by a few methods within Python.

First, it can be created from a 2-dimensional `numpy` array.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-19, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 175}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 574, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189717994, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="E0aCFaw_7iuO", outputId="c709622c-c485-4685-9732-fce133b999f2"}
rng = np.random.RandomState(25)
d1 = pd.DataFrame(rng.normal(0,1, (4,5)))
d1
```

<!-- #region id="H-v2GR5T7iuO" -->
You will notice that it creates default column names, that are merely the column number, starting from 0. We can also create the column names and row index (similar to the `Series` index we saw earlier) directly during creation.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-20, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 175}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 458, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189718406, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="jLTuDace7iuO", outputId="17b895fc-2bdf-4f96-f143-3eaa3178cf17"}
d2 = pd.DataFrame(rng.normal(0,1, (4, 5)), 
                  columns = ['A','B','C','D','E'], 
                  index = ['a','b','c','d'])
d2
```

<!-- #region id="7WLZgW-h7iuO" -->
> We could also create a `DataFrame` from a list of lists, as long as things line up, just as we showed for `numpy` arrays. However, to me, other ways, including the `dict` method below, make more sense.
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="f8kROFMZ7iuO" -->
We can change the column names (which can be extracted and replaced with the `columns` attribute) and the index values (using the `index` attribute).
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-21, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 473, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189719193, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="kxefJt-77iuO", outputId="52b74782-6389-4ef6-e8fd-54ee8b48a828"}

```

```{python 02-python-pandas-22, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 175}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 464, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189719414, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="zaqKPymB7iuO", outputId="2e836658-29f4-4ecd-d4ab-9ef2e23ac4fa"}
d2.columns = pd.Index(['V'+str(i) for i in range(1,6)]) # Index creates the right objects for both column names and row names, which can be extracted and changed with the `index` attribute
d2
```

<!-- #region id="m7NsWUT77iuO" -->
You can also extract data from a homogeneous `DataFrame` to a `numpy` array
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-24, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 377, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189720374, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="oKRtm2o_7iuO", outputId="5d875825-b27b-4653-900e-aa08c1c7c17f"}

There is some more detail about the `object` data type in the Python Tools for Data Science ([notebook](01_python_tools_ds.ipynb#object), [PDF](01_python_tools_ds.pdf)) document.

The other easy way to create a `DataFrame` is from a `dict` object, where each component object is either a list or a numpy array, and is homogeneous in type. One exception is if a component is of size 1; then it is repeated to meet the needs of the `DataFrame`'s dimensions

```{python 02-python-pandas-25, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 637, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189721656, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="F2oYyy6G7iuO", outputId="cdb52a99-d06e-4460-9597-c8fa07ac5938"}

```{python 02-python-pandas-26, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 659, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189721928, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="Eqg306c67iuO", outputId="c2352cbb-210c-4861-c13f-cefa70b2349e"}

```

<!-- #region id="ROynTfp07iuO" -->
We note that C is a date object, E is a category object, and F is a text/string object. pandas has excellent time series capabilities (having origins in FinTech), and the `TimeStamp` function creates datetime objects which can be queried and manipulated in Python. We'll describe category data in the next section.

Let's look at slicing a `DataFrame`

#### Extracting rows and columns

There are two extractor functions in `pandas`:

+ `loc` extracts by label (index label, column label, slice of labels, etc.
+ `iloc` extracts by index (integers, slice objects, etc.

<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-31, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 309, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189725019, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="bbYu1VH07iuO", outputId="66bef075-d8d4-4dc0-ad27-f3832a6269ce"}

                  index = ['a','b','c','d','e'],

<!-- #region id="hmbWjpT17iuO" -->
First, let's see what naively slicing this `DataFrame` does.

```{python 02-python-pandas-32, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 293, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189725558, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="aCEaXSAY7iuO", outputId="b3d50d67-ca12-4ad2-ba8e-e63d98fcaa75"}
df2['one']
```

<!-- #region id="756Y98oB7iuO" -->
Ok, that works. It grabs one column from the dataset. How about the dot notation?
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-33, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 540, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189726335, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="1YpTX0vs7iuO", outputId="35e343d6-45cc-4edc-b853-a51c42ed8f50"}

<!-- #region id="SlWBowVO7iuO" -->
Let's see what this produces.

```{python 02-python-pandas-34, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 328, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189726642, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="bYGIhDkZ7iuO", outputId="11c116ca-1949-4c66-88e5-4944fe744b01"}

df2.one['b']
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-36, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 297, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189727542, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="L8ziIfkw7iuO", outputId="9290ca63-384d-40c5-f4e1-9e24444ca256"}
df2.one['b':'d']

```{python 02-python-pandas-37, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 343, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189727857, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="ePN4JeA37iuO", outputId="6e419abb-40ef-4119-a526-97498792f68e"}
df2.one[:3]

<!-- #region id="-f_hsBTP7iuO" -->
Ok, so we have all the `Series` slicing available. The problem here is in semantics, in that we are grabbing one column and then slicing the rows. That doesn't quite work with our sense that a `DataFrame` is a rectangle with rows and columns, and we tend to think of rows, then columns. 

Let's see if we can do column slicing with this. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-38, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 550, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189728625, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="khQLBlci7iuO", outputId="21ba35af-bf19-44e3-c706-9c77c231648f"}
df2[:'two']
```

<!-- #region id="AmEz-P8J7iuO" -->
That's not what we want, of course. It's giving back the entire data frame. We'll come back to this.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-39, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 449, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189728962, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="SLMxLpc67iuO", outputId="d4db5ba9-5499-44ef-e11b-673f68b885cf"}
df2[['one','three']]
```

<!-- #region id="CKYuU_Rw7iuO" -->
That works correctly though. We can give a list of column names. Ok. 

How about row slices?

```{python 02-python-pandas-40, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 143}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 461, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189729413, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="EtddJfNW7iuO", outputId="6de874d1-d2ab-45fa-eb6c-88f12c95a52f"}
#df2['a'] # Doesn't work

```

<!-- #region id="5-emBYox7iuO" -->
Ok, that works. It slices rows, but includes the largest index, like a `Series` but unlike `numpy` arrays. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-41, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 112}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 555, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189729939, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="fO4MjGp97iuO", outputId="11718cac-c5b5-4e47-b156-5451ae660ecc"}
df2[0:2]
```

<!-- #region id="w9bU6xYM7iuO" -->
Slices by location work too, but use the `numpy` slicing rules. 
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="X6liTBkj7iuO" -->
This entire extraction method becomes confusing. Let's simplify things for this, and then move on to more consistent ways to extract elements of a `DataFrame`. Let's agree on two things. If we're going the direct extraction route, 

1. We will extract single columns of a `DataFrame` with `[]` or `.`, i.e., `df2['one']` or `df2.one`
1. We will extract slices of rows of a `DataFrame` using location only, i.e., `df2[:3]`. 

For everything else, we'll use two functions, `loc` and `iloc`.

+ `loc` extracts elements like a matrix, using index and columns
+ `iloc` extracts elements like a matrix, using location
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-42, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 451, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189730426, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="KU0HTiUK7iuO", outputId="2bf8a5dd-11d1-4b20-f697-4da3de44cc6f"}
df2.loc[:,'one':'three']
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-43, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 175}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 346, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189731168, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="H9TWj9j97iuO", outputId="45ff3ade-fa5d-47aa-e908-c67c8edda23d"}
df2.loc['a':'d',:]
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-44, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 497, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189731543, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="Y8ZrjpZM7iuO", outputId="52c39696-3957-4b97-c986-b80b12535c7a"}
df2.loc['b', 'three']
```

<!-- #region id="2sWcNsWM7iuO" -->
So `loc` works just like a matrix, but with `pandas` slicing rules (include largest index)
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-45, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 364, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189731874, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="RphGhiEJ7iuO", outputId="28dd8877-e59e-45b3-ae10-fb5791474803"}
df2.iloc[:,1:4]
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-46, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 112}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 429, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189732165, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="dzxkWtcB7iuO", outputId="eace85b0-f084-4ab3-d424-e0d8617cf81b"}
df2.iloc[1:3,:]
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-47, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 112}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 489, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189732462, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="aMBcKlAq7iuO", outputId="8ac40a5e-6a76-4668-d876-71cb061be5e3"}
df2.iloc[1:3, 1:4]
```

<!-- #region id="dwFSg_Yu7iuO" -->
`iloc` slices like a matrix, but uses `numpy` slicing conventions (does **not** include highest index)

If we want to extract a single element from a dataset, there are two functions available, `iat` and `at`, with behavior corresponding to `iloc` and `loc`, respectively.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 841, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189733381, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="mVrpuMPg7iuO", outputId="6027a578-99b8-467d-858f-f485688c724e"}
df2.iat[2,3]
```

```{python colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 564, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189733382, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="w77YO2I57iuO", outputId="56613b75-eeb7-4497-f13d-5bdedafa4b3a"}
df2.at['b','three']
```


<!-- #region id="NrW8vGID7iuO" -->
#### Boolean selection

We can also use tests to extract data from a `DataFrame`. For example, we can extract only rows where column labeled `one` is greater than 3. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-48, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 340, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189733585, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="aSdPEKE77iuO", outputId="3923ece6-e15e-4782-c9dd-12d2abcc5977"}
df2[df2.one > 3]
```

<!-- #region id="PbG5C8Y57iuP" -->
We can also do composite tests. Here we ask for rows where `one` is greater than 3 and `three` is less than 9

```{python 02-python-pandas-49, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 245, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189734193, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="PajSpyXB7iuP", outputId="1e009de3-0893-482a-acee-faf3f5a8613b"}
df2[(df2.one > 3) & (df2.three < 9)]

#### `query`

`DataFrame`'s have a `query` method allowing selection using a Python expression

```{python 02-python-pandas-50, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 363}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 420, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189734961, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="NZr9SrbJ7iuP", outputId="2e60aa3f-141d-4afc-ca2a-9be2aebe18c4"}
n = 10
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.rand(n, 3), columns = list('abc'))
df

```{python 02-python-pandas-51, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 112}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 313, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189735244, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="GUeIQrDd7iuP", outputId="3b354faf-7f6c-4fb2-cf4e-f98937541b08"}

<!-- #region id="kQ06ZKZP7iuP" -->
### Categorical data

`pandas` provides a `Categorical` function and a `category` object type to Python. This type is analogous to the `factor` data type in R. It is meant to address categorical or discrete variables, where we need to use them in analyses. Categorical variables typically take on a small number of unique values, like gender, blood type, country of origin, race, etc. 

You can create categorical `Series` in a couple of ways:
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-53, executionInfo={'elapsed': 357, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189739488, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="-dMU2ppq7iuP"}
s = pd.Series(['a','b','c'], dtype='category')
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-54, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 390, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189739854, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="8MzzD9Tg7iuP", outputId="d6bc7f14-c461-40ea-e216-ff055d0f7104"}
df = pd.DataFrame({
    'A':3.,
    'B':rng.random_sample(5),
    'C': pd.Timestamp('20200512'),
    'D': np.array([6] * 5),
    'E': pd.Categorical(['yes','no','no','yes','no']),
    'F': 'NIH'})
df['F'].astype('category')
```

<!-- #region id="TgjzGCPr7iuP" -->
You can also create `DataFrame`'s where each column is categorical
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-55, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 659, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189740807, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="E36cKmXc7iuP", outputId="6903850d-bf1c-43ec-ce3f-e5c17e8494a7"}
df = pd.DataFrame({'A': list('abcd'), 'B': list('bdca')})
df_cat = df.astype('category')
df_cat.dtypes
```

<!-- #region id="3blDH_qz7iuP" -->
You can explore categorical data in a variety of ways
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-56, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 411, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189741069, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="R5X4GAYK7iuP", outputId="22310b3b-c453-49fb-e4e5-cbe0d5d35712"}
df_cat['A'].describe()
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-57, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 362, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189741276, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="VU8yY9EM7iuP", outputId="f3cc93e1-7539-49d0-ec6a-8acf0cd7c814"}
df['A'].value_counts()
```

<!-- #region id="FnkVj3X17iuP" -->
One issue with categories is that, if a particular level of a category is not seen before, it can create an error. So you can pre-specify the categories you expect
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-58, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 482, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189741844, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="Fau8q4on7iuQ", outputId="8912d808-74f8-482d-9b84-a8c17b4330a2"}
df_cat['B'] = pd.Categorical(list('aabb'), categories = ['a','b','c','d'])
df_cat['B'].value_counts()
```

<!-- #region id="ov7opk5j7iuQ" -->
#### Re-organizing categories

In categorical data, there is often the concept of a "first" or "reference" category, and an ordering of categories. This tends to be important in both visualization as well as in regression modeling. Both aspects of a category can be addressed using the `reorder_categories` function.

In our earlier example, we can see that the `A` variable has 4 categories, with the "first" category being "a".
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 350, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189742162, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="omdX8d9R7iuQ", outputId="818d2520-375e-4c5b-9355-75f117805776"}
df_cat.A
```

<!-- #region id="LnbzKiyt7iuQ" -->
Suppose we want to change this ordering to the reverse ordering, where
"d" is the "first" category, and then it goes in reverse order. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 848, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189743099, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="BujpTwSo7iuQ", outputId="8a1257b4-0cb8-486d-cd77-5a38000702a3"}
df_cat['A'] = df_cat.A.cat.reorder_categories(['d','c','b','a'])
df_cat.A
```

<!-- #region id="eMOegnsN7iuQ" -->
### Missing data

Both `numpy` and `pandas` allow for missing values, which are a reality in data science. The missing values are coded as `np.nan`. Let's create some data and force some missing values
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-59, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 417, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189743100, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="McMrXSun7iuQ", outputId="6a4d78cf-0fd8-47e1-faea-978dbb8f22a5"}
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(5, 3), index = ['a','c','e', 'f','g'], columns = ['one','two','three']) # pre-specify index and column names
df['four'] = 20 # add a column named "four", which will all be 20
df['five'] = df['one'] > 0
df
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-60, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 190}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 613, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189743496, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="2Vw4Ibi77iuQ", outputId="43efd041-2fe7-445d-f4b4-1352c2ea2550"}
df2 = df.reindex(['a','b','c','d','e','f','g'])
df2.style.applymap(lambda x: 'background-color:yellow', subset = pd.IndexSlice[['b','d'],:])
```

<!-- #region id="fxohxkxJ7iuQ" -->
The code above is creating new blank rows based on the new index values, some of which are present in the existing data and some of which are missing.

We can create *masks* of the data indicating where missing values reside in a data set.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-61, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 269}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 472, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189743932, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="A5xKmj2x7iuQ", outputId="842203e3-4038-4fdc-9557-e136a59bde6d"}
df2.isna()
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-62, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 721, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189744304, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="Fd1-LpqG7iuQ", outputId="7f6813f8-6f3e-4471-8db8-a0601e3e8755"}
df2['one'].notna()
```

<!-- #region id="WArS4StG7iuQ" -->
We can obtain complete data by dropping any row that has any missing value. This is called *complete case analysis*, and you should be very careful using it. It is *only* valid if we belive that the missingness is missing at random, and not related to some characteristic of the data or the data gathering process. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-63, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 539, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189744558, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="QxsgDKsg7iuQ", outputId="3cdc7211-65cd-4f5c-cea0-4c393d94a1f7"}
df2.dropna(how='any')
```

<!-- #region id="HXVYdJS-7iuQ" -->
You can also fill in, or *impute*, missing values. This can be done using a single value..
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-64, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 190}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 372, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189744910, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="cyPO9BkU7iuQ", outputId="02ab6607-12e2-4178-adc2-c47986811273"}
out1 = df2.fillna(value = 5)

out1.style.applymap(lambda x: 'background-color:yellow', subset = pd.IndexSlice[['b','d'],:])
```

<!-- #region id="ksk6nDg97iuQ" -->
or a computed value like a column mean
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-65, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 190}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 449, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189745677, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="im1ugpBX7iuQ", outputId="5aefc838-6117-467f-c964-dacb16195892"}
df3 = df2.copy()
df3 = df3.select_dtypes(exclude=[object])   # remove non-numeric columns
out2 = df3.fillna(df3.mean())  # df3.mean() computes column-wise means

out2.style.applymap(lambda x: 'background-color:yellow', subset = pd.IndexSlice[['b','d'],:])
```

<!-- #region id="QsGlcTuk7iuQ" -->
You can also impute based on the principle of *last value carried forward* which is common in time series. This means that the missing value is imputed with the previous recorded value. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-66, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 190}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 585, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189746188, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="9zhEsmzH7iuQ", outputId="65eeafc0-0be5-4fdc-f961-448402eeb85c"}
out3 = df2.fillna(method = 'ffill') # Fill forward

out3.style.applymap(lambda x: 'background-color:yellow', subset = pd.IndexSlice[['b','d'],:])
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-67, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 190}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 773, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189746651, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="hNoqWV557iuQ", outputId="06265355-a940-450b-b67b-b1752852c418"}
out4 = df2.fillna(method = 'bfill') # Fill backward

out4.style.applymap(lambda x: 'background-color:yellow', subset = pd.IndexSlice[['b','d'],:])
```

## Data transformation

### Arithmetic operations

If you have a `Series` or `DataFrame` that is all numeric, you can add or multiply single numbers to all the elements together.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-68, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 790, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189747025, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="ocagG3yu7iuQ", outputId="5a4a6a33-3349-42da-b1f5-f6430e1e69e3"}
A = pd.DataFrame(np.random.randn(4,5))
print(A)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-69, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 494, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189747025, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="3WZmnJeN7iuQ", outputId="119f2b09-60cf-4ad7-e1f8-bc1a683bd796"}
print(A + 6)

```{python 02-python-pandas-70, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 539, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189747278, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="DCPskZrd7iuQ", outputId="f66cf5a0-56f4-4b24-da02-2224e71c9014"}

<!-- #region id="dcuT5Kmu7iuQ" -->
If you have two compatible (same dimension) numeric `DataFrame`s, you can add, subtract, multiply and divide elementwise
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-71, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 388, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189747628, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="gLyHlPg27iuQ", outputId="cdb8fdb5-d623-483d-c2c4-2a43a3aa4602"}

```{python 02-python-pandas-72, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 355, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189747819, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="jEexxA-z7iuQ", outputId="af4a7d01-a0ab-4e76-c4dc-db6a7f12aaae"}

<!-- #region id="QkbJOGzS7iuQ" -->
If you have a `Series` with the same number of elements as the number of columns of a `DataFrame`, you can do arithmetic operations, with each element of the `Series` acting upon each column of the `DataFrame`
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-73, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 301, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189748206, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="OC4r9-cx7iuQ", outputId="4d1ff62d-65cd-4634-82d5-397c47a70242"}

<!-- #region id="u-lLbHog7iuR" -->
This idea can be used to standardize a dataset, i.e. make each column have mean 0 and standard deviation 1.

means = A.mean(axis=0)

(A - means)/stds

<!-- #region id="3HQ3keyj7iuR" -->
### Concatenation of data sets

Let's create some example data sets
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-76, executionInfo={'elapsed': 303, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189749986, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="uHsgkc1f7iuR"}
df1 = pd.DataFrame({'A': ['a'+str(i) for i in range(4)],
    'B': ['b'+str(i) for i in range(4)],
    'C': ['c'+str(i) for i in range(4)],
    'D': ['d'+str(i) for i in range(4)]})

df2 =  pd.DataFrame({'A': ['a'+str(i) for i in range(4,8)],
    'B': ['b'+str(i) for i in range(4,8)],
    'C': ['c'+str(i) for i in range(4,8)],
    'D': ['d'+str(i) for i in range(4,8)]})
df3 =  pd.DataFrame({'A': ['a'+str(i) for i in range(8,12)],
    'B': ['b'+str(i) for i in range(8,12)],
    'C': ['c'+str(i) for i in range(8,12)],
    'D': ['d'+str(i) for i in range(8,12)]})
```

<!-- #region id="uDmjVBV37iuR" -->
We can concatenate these `DataFrame` objects by row
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-77, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 524, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189750671, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="uqfbkxZZ7iuR", outputId="6c629de2-3d55-4cb2-f325-444ee8f0abe9"}
row_concatenate = pd.concat([df1, df2, df3])
print(row_concatenate)
```

<!-- #region id="KZ3ee2y97iuR" -->
This stacks the dataframes together. They are literally stacked, as is evidenced by the index values being repeated. 
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="FKbpbXTu7iuR" -->
This same exercise can be done by the `append` function
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-78, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 426}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 456, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189751555, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="PYu3lCqO7iuR", outputId="019ef847-ea77-4ceb-eac9-47947edcd8c2"}
df1.append(df2).append(df3)
```

<!-- #region id="cEwDHjnb7iuR" -->
Suppose we want to append a new row to `df1`. Lets create a new row.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-79, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 300}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 581, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189752218, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="IF1Hu_zv7iuR", outputId="8cc51f4a-4676-4e52-a66c-a74c8c49114a"}
new_row = pd.Series(['n1','n2','n3','n4'])
pd.concat([df1, new_row])
```

<!-- #region id="4pumlOQp7iuR" -->
That's a lot of missing values. The issue is that the we don't have column names in the `new_row`, and the indices are the same, so pandas tries to append it my making a new column. The solution is to make it a `DataFrame`.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-80, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 412, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189752504, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="hy1ZVDvl7iuR", outputId="905018b8-3ff5-459f-8f4c-76ad205dbbd1"}
new_row = pd.DataFrame([['n1','n2','n3','n4']], columns = ['A','B','C','D'])
print(new_row)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-81, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 339, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189752888, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="unLa8Hie7iuR", outputId="2de08285-f660-41cc-9d0c-1ae15c4bd9df"}
pd.concat([df1, new_row])
```

<!-- #region id="47K3JPOS7iuR" -->
or
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-82, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 437, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189753661, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="zxlswTTo7iuR", outputId="3f8cf4c7-e7c9-44dd-ad3d-b05f94cf342c"}
df1.append(new_row)
```

<!-- #region id="g2c42nrT7iuR" -->
#### Adding columns
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-83, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 175}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 483, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189754122, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="KKtG27tu7iuR", outputId="563e4b3f-dae0-4361-ad54-c679c6c26f9a"}
pd.concat([df1,df2,df3], axis = 1)
```

<!-- #region id="iWSxmxhH7iuR" -->
The option `axis=1` ensures that concatenation happens by columns. The default value `axis = 0` concatenates by rows.
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="xoJK6YBM7iuR" -->
Let's play a little game. Let's change the column names of `df2` and `df3` so they are not the same as `df1`.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-84, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 426}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 619, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189755047, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="VxVaAYqD7iuR", outputId="3c80af04-af25-46a4-99e6-a1ba3737a859"}
df2.columns = ['E','F','G','H']
df3.columns = ['A','D','F','H']
pd.concat([df1,df2,df3])
```

<!-- #region id="gZhJ_nGt7iuR" -->
Now pandas ensures that all column names are represented in the new data frame, but with missing values where the row indices and column indices are mismatched. Some of this can be avoided by only joining on common columns. This is done using the `join` option ir `concat`. The default value is 'outer`, which is what you see. above
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-85, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 300}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 862, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189755718, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="UeBf_74W7iuR", outputId="4d292f29-b440-4de9-d6b6-a7dd743f51df"}
pd.concat([df1, df3], join = 'inner')
```

<!-- #region id="8aKZSPL87iuR" -->
You can do the same thing when joining by rows, using `axis = 0` and `join="inner"` to only join on rows with matching indices. Reminder that the indices are just labels and happen to be the row numbers by default. 
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="RFapojN27iuR" -->
### Merging data sets
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="3ZxmxAOM7iuR" -->
For this section we'll use a set of data from a survey, also used by Daniel Chen in "Pandas for Everyone"
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-86, executionInfo={'elapsed': 1691, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189757594, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="1Lxgh-SW7iuR"}

print(site)

```{python 02-python-pandas-89, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 972, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189757596, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="_CywZ39R7iuR", outputId="a8634cbf-a548-4f3a-b4a6-4dbff58802fe"}
print(survey)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-90, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 714, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189757597, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="n_tcj-Ei7iuR", outputId="0b0922ed-30a5-4ca5-cfad-adee00434171"}
print(visited)
```

<!-- #region id="QbX2Ofb47iuR" -->
There are basically four kinds of joins:

| pandas | R          | SQL         | Description                     |
| ------ | ---------- | ----------- | ------------------------------- |
| left   | left_join  | left outer  | keep all rows on left           |
| right  | right_join | right outer | keep all rows on right          |
| outer  | outer_join | full outer  | keep all rows from both         |
| inner  | inner_join | inner       | keep only rows with common keys |
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="wklSD06-7iuR" -->
![](graphs/joins.png)

The terms `left` and `right` refer to which data set you call first and second respectively. 

We start with an left join

<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-91, executionInfo={'elapsed': 533, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189758173, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="q6oz2Y7E7iuR"}
s2v_merge = survey.merge(visited, left_on = 'taken',right_on = 'ident', how = 'left')
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-92, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 279, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189758173, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="27hjSJ5L7iuR", outputId="f07b0135-64d1-49e9-d1e3-c99497a9cdea"}
print(s2v_merge)
```

<!-- #region id="BXe7nHS17iuR" -->
Here, the left dataset is `survey` and the right one is `visited`. Since we're doing a left join, we keed all the rows from `survey` and add columns from `visited`, matching on the common key, called "taken" in one dataset and "ident" in the other. Note that the rows of `visited` are repeated as needed to line up with all the rows with common "taken" values. 

We can now add location information, where the common key is the site code
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-93, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 648, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189758958, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="SW19R_bt7iuR", outputId="207e34b0-a7e5-49f5-db83-e61f251994a5"}
s2v2loc_merge = s2v_merge.merge(site, how = 'left', left_on = 'site', right_on = 'name')
print(s2v2loc_merge)
```

<!-- #region id="fOygzEdG7iuR" -->
Lastly, we add the person information to this dataset.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-94, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 379, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189759180, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="0E5L8Jgl7iuR", outputId="bbe5131f-20ff-471c-a425-f34d9ea67b93"}
merged = s2v2loc_merge.merge(person, how = 'left', left_on = 'person', right_on = 'ident')
print(merged.head())
```

<!-- #region id="aydInkru7iuR" -->
You can merge based on multiple columns as long as they match up. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-95, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 587, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189759817, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="IdXkc3SB7iuR", outputId="bbb4f585-1965-47b6-eb9a-2eba9d58a72a"}
ps = person.merge(survey, left_on = 'ident', right_on = 'person')
vs = visited.merge(survey, left_on = 'ident', right_on = 'taken')
print(ps)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-96, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 354, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189759817, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="l-kTVOrn7iuR", outputId="67ed05e7-14ee-4575-8323-c088b5d24757"}
print(vs)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-97, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 286, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189759967, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="OJNZdgJB7iuR", outputId="d675dc80-cafe-4605-bc6d-0b7f37f43ce7"}
ps_vs = ps.merge(vs, 
                left_on = ['ident','taken', 'quant','reading'],
                right_on = ['person','ident','quant','reading']) # The keys need to correspond
ps_vs.head()
```

<!-- #region id="scd4GU3S7iuR" -->
Note that since there are common column names, the merge appends `_x` and `_y` to denote which column came from the left and right, respectively.

<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="fi76Fb3V7iuR" -->
### Tidy data principles and reshaping datasets

The tidy data principle is a principle espoused by Dr. Hadley Wickham, one of the foremost R developers. [Tidy data](http://vita.had.co.nz/papers/tidy-data.pdf) is a structure for datasets to make them more easily analyzed on computers. The basic principles are

+ Each row is an observation
+ Each column is a variable
+ Each type of observational unit forms a table

> Tidy data is tidy in one way. Untidy data can be untidy in many ways

Let's look at some examples.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-98, executionInfo={'elapsed': 1986, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189762445, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="LGiLqSyo7iuR"}

filenames = sorted(glob('data/table*.csv')) # find files matching pattern. I know there are 6 of them
table1, table2, table3, table4a, table4b, table5 = [pd.read_csv(f) for f in filenames] # Use a list comprehension
```

<!-- #region id="2G9lgUGw7iuR" -->
This code imports data from 6 files matching a pattern. Python allows multiple assignments on the left of the `=`, and as each dataset is imported, it gets assigned in order to the variables on the left. In the second line I sort the file names so that they match the order in which I'm storing them in the 3rd line. The function `glob` does pattern-matching of file names. 

The following tables refer to the number of TB cases and population in Afghanistan, Brazil and China in 1999 and 2000

### Melting (unpivoting) data

Melting is the operation of collapsing multiple columns into 2 columns, where one column is formed by the old column names, and the other by the corresponding values. Some columns may be kept fixed and their data are repeated to maintain the interrelationships between the variables.

We'll start with loading some data on income and religion in the US from the Pew Research Center.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-105, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 877, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189763666, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="N4ixttSz7iuR", outputId="37ce4213-6e57-4d25-e53a-694eef4faf29"}
pew = pd.read_csv('data/pew.csv')
print(pew.head())
```

<!-- #region id="PNc7rdLu7iuR" -->
This dataset is considered in "wide" format. There are several issues with it, including the fact that column headers have data. Those column headers are income groups, that should be a column by tidy principles. Our job is to turn this dataset into "long" format with a column for income group. 

We will use the function `melt` to achieve this. This takes a few parameters:

+ **id_vars** is a list of variables that will remain as is
+ **value_vars** is a list of column nmaes that we will melt (or unpivot). By default, it will melt all columns not mentioned in id_vars
+ **var_name** is a string giving the name of the new column created by the headers (default: `variable`)
+ **value_name** is a string giving the name of the new column created by the values (default: `value`)

<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-106, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 511, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189763854, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="fpL2qH1G7iuR", outputId="336539b8-b1ac-49c3-b118-742966ab5c18"}
pew_long = pew.melt(id_vars = ['religion'], var_name = 'income_group', value_name = 'count')
print(pew_long.head())
```

<!-- #region id="5Y0PK7WV7iuR" -->
### Separating columns containing multiple variables

We will use an Ebola dataset to illustrate this principle
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-107, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 863, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189764636, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="uGs7ibnA7iuR", outputId="f45a2844-ea52-4c78-e286-79f450bd7b3e"}
ebola = pd.read_csv('data/country_timeseries.csv')
print(ebola.head())
```

<!-- #region id="VFimPTmw7iuR" -->
Note that for each country we have two columns -- one for cases (number infected) and one for deaths. Ideally we want one column for country, one for cases and one for deaths. 

The first step will be to melt this data sets so that the column headers in question from a column and the corresponding data forms a second column.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-108, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 425, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189764636, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="JX2Mty1O7iuR", outputId="a36fb657-317e-41cf-ab24-6214bf30a185"}
ebola_long = ebola.melt(id_vars = ['Date','Day'])
print(ebola_long.head())
```

<!-- #region id="QmhYzJNq7iuR" -->
We now need to split the data in the `variable` column to make two columns. One will contain the country name and the other either Cases or Deaths. We will use some string manipulation functions that we will see later to achieve this.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-109, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 658, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189765386, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="tRmpAV8K7iuR", outputId="2d24cb62-6db9-42a8-c06f-71ab65b8b391"}
variable_split = ebola_long['variable'].str.split('_', expand=True) # split on the `_` character
print(variable_split[:5])
```

<!-- #region id="2H2EP5iO7iuR" -->
The `expand=True` option forces the creation of an `DataFrame` rather than a list
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-110, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 384, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189765562, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="h-KF0K0n7iuR", outputId="0aa8acde-fd42-481f-90e3-5f1c05a51542"}
type(variable_split)
```

<!-- #region id="zqpUkytT7iuR" -->
We can now concatenate this to the original data
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-111, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 361, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189766246, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="iIfopfgm7iuR", outputId="a1d8ad8c-e0dc-4356-a83e-ac74adb1df55"}
variable_split.columns = ['status','country']

ebola_parsed = pd.concat([ebola_long, variable_split], axis = 1)

ebola_parsed.drop('variable', axis = 1, inplace=True) # Remove the column named "variable" and replace the old data with the new one in the same location

print(ebola_parsed.head())
```

<!-- #region id="diXeuPuQ7iuR" -->
### Pivot/spread datasets

If we wanted to, we could also make two columns based on cases and deaths, so for each country and date you could easily read off the cases and deaths. This is achieved using the `pivot_table` function.

In the `pivot_table` syntax, `index` refers to the columns we don't want to change, `columns` refers to the column whose values will form the column names of the new columns, and `values` is the name of the column that will form the values in the pivoted dataset. 
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-112, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 455}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 329, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189766981, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="O10RjHYJ7iuR", outputId="1d262bef-054b-4416-e8cd-2dc77ce88723"}
ebola_parsed.pivot_table(index = ['Date','Day', 'country'], columns = 'status', values = 'value')
```

<!-- #region id="X85mSpun7iuR" -->
This creates something called `MultiIndex` in the `pandas` `DataFrame`. This is useful in some advanced cases, but here, we just want a normal `DataFrame` back. We can achieve that by using the `reset_index` function.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-113, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 424}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 680, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189767764, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="4e5nvuM37iuR", outputId="07639ce8-f1c6-47c1-f3e9-af1ac2d8f0f5"}
ebola_parsed.pivot_table(index = ['Date','Day','country'], columns = 'status', values = 'value').reset_index()
```

<!-- #region id="tsDUIh-57iuR" -->
Pivoting is a 2-column to many-column operation, with the number of columns formed depending on the number of unique values present in the column of the original data that is entered into the `columns` argument of `pivot_table`
<!-- #endregion -->

## Data aggregation and split-apply-combine

We'll use the Gapminder dataset for this section
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-114, executionInfo={'elapsed': 682, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189769104, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="J1DcCvSK7iuR"}

<!-- #region id="8Sv0uiDd7iuR" -->
The paradigm we will be exploring is often called *split-apply-combine* or MapReduce or grouped aggregation. The basic idea is that you split a data set up by some feature, apply a recipe to each piece, compute the result, and then put the results back together into a dataset. This can be described in teh following schematic.
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="9ZENnYbn7iuR" -->
![](graphs/split-apply-combine.png)
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="aqc9sqw87iuR" -->
`pandas` is set up for this. It features the `groupby` function that allows the "split" part of the operation. We can then apply a function to each part and put it back together. Let's see how.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-115, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 206}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 260, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189769567, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="YHYJ9vMP7iuR", outputId="267c6b45-b927-49c8-96d0-dba7a926c5fa"}
df.head()

```{python 02-python-pandas-127, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 238}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 414, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189775467, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="RRerL_Dt7iuS", outputId="9b58c23e-2a45-4eba-dfb6-9d5aedff25ec"}

<!-- #region id="WhnsvkQS7iuS" -->
You can also use functions from other modules, or your own functions in this aggregation work.
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-129, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 753, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189776634, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="SIdmom007iuS", outputId="1361e6c2-5656-434f-ee3f-35155c1027bd"}
df.groupby('continent').lifeExp.agg(np.mean)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-130, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 699, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189776635, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="C474cBan7iuS", outputId="0a3868e1-7057-47f9-8352-bb2f57d37ec6"}
def my_mean(values):
    n = len(values)
    sum = 0
    for value in values:
        sum += value
    return(sum/n)

df.groupby('continent').lifeExp.agg(my_mean)
```

<!-- #region id="KGcVIjUb7iuS" -->
You can do many functions at once
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-131, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 457}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 298, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189776879, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="lwIYZMOK7iuS", outputId="91b6337c-ad4a-480c-e094-4c523234e776"}

```

<!-- #region id="qDC7LTC17iuS" -->
You can also aggregate on different columns at the same time by passing a `dict` to the `agg` function
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-132, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 426}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 785, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189777766, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="-i6Dbwyf7iuS", outputId="4b3cd685-3dd1-48f6-ebe8-02aea02dd6a3"}
df.groupby('year').agg({'lifeExp': np.mean,'pop': np.median,'gdpPercap': np.median}).reset_index()
```

<!-- #region id="deHrkYxM7iuS" -->
#### Transformation
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="8oFEkaJ57iuS" -->
You can do grouped transformations using this same method. We will compute the z-score for each year, i.e. we will substract the average life expectancy and divide by the standard deviation
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-133, executionInfo={'elapsed': 722, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189778430, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="fwYZfcQ57iuS"}
def my_zscore(values):
    m = np.mean(values)
    s = np.std(values)
    return((values - m)/s)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-134, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 576, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189778649, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="t7FfHtOP7iuS", outputId="562a3198-6eb9-43eb-8db3-2f55bf1f3920"}
df.groupby('year').lifeExp.transform(my_zscore)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-135, executionInfo={'elapsed': 363, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189778649, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="CT2KKR547iuS"}
df['lifeExp_z'] = df.groupby('year').lifeExp.transform(my_zscore)
```

```{python 02-python-pandas-136, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/'}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 490, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189778851, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="UfKEHTOL7iuS", outputId="f4d3c70b-2a8e-421e-e570-9395dd3edea5"}
df.groupby('year').lifeExp_z.mean()
```

#### Filter
<!-- #endregion -->

<!-- #region id="Ddx8RITA7iuS" -->
We can split the dataset by values of one variable, and filter out those splits that fail some criterion. The following code only keeps countries with a population of at least 10 million at some point during the study period
<!-- #endregion -->

```{python 02-python-pandas-137, colab={'base_uri': 'https://localhost:8080/', 'height': 424}, executionInfo={'elapsed': 451, 'status': 'ok', 'timestamp': 1607189779480, 'user': {'displayName': 'Gaby Gerlach', 'photoUrl': '', 'userId': '11117434220237101401'}, 'user_tz': 300}, id="oUc3i1y47iuS", outputId="6ab895f2-f9a8-40ac-a460-6a96879e5d02"}
df.groupby('country').filter(lambda d: d['pop'].max() > 10000000)
```
